Authors:
Samsuddin Ahmad Syazwan, Ahmad Mohd Farid, Abdullah Mohd
Zaki, Wan Azhar Wan Muhd Azrul, Su-See Lee, Rozi Mohamed
Title:
: Survey, identification and pathogenicity of the fungi
associated with Ceratocystis wilt disease on Acacia mangium plantations
in Malaysia
Keywords:
Survey, fungus, morphology, pathogenicity, host
range.
Abstract:
Surveys for wilt disease were conducted in selected Acacia
mangium plantations in the states of Sarawak, Johor, Terengganu, and
Pahang in Malaysia. Results of the surveys revealed the occurrence of
the wilt disease in three of the five plantations surveyed with disease
incidence ranging from 7.53 to 13.6%. Signs of wood-boring insects, bark
peeling due to squirrel activity and singling wounds were often
associated with disease occurrence. The fungus most often isolated from
the diseased trees was Ceratocystis. Cultural and morphological
characteristics of the perithecia, ascospores, conidia and ostiolar
hyphae identified the fungus as C. fimbriata. Phylogenetic analysis of
the combined ITS and EF-1ÔÅ° regions grouped the isolates together within
C. fimbriata sensu stricto complex supported by 44% bootstrap values.
Pathogenicity tests were conducted using six of the isolates on six to
nine-month-old healthy A. mangium seedlings. The results demonstrated
that all the isolates were pathogenic with mortality beginning as early
as two weeks after inoculation. However, ANOVA showed a significant
difference in pathogenicity among the fungal isolates. The results also
showed that pathogen aggressiveness was not correlated with geographical
origin. A host range test was also conducted using C. fimbriata isolates
SSB3 and FRIM1162 against A. mangium, Aquilaria malaccensis, Eurycoma
longifolia, Hevea brasiliensis, Khaya ivorensis and Tectona grandis.
This test showed that only A. mangium was susceptible to Ceratocystis
isolates SSB3 and FRIM1162. The other species remained healthy with no
symptoms of infection even after seven weeks and had significantly
better survival compared to A. mangium.
